Description: Limestone figure of a enthroned human figure with a ram's head (Zeus-Ammon type).
Findspot: Found/Acquired: Cyprus, The findspot is not given in the register but, because a later group given by Hoskier is said to have come from the Cesnola collection (GR 1936,12-30.1-3), this may have come from from the same source. Note however that examples of this type have also been found in shrines in the Aegean and Naukratis in Egypt. (?)
Curator's comments: Thrones with ram supports are common in the late CA to early Hellenistic periods (Coenaerts and Samaes 2006, with further references; also Buchholz 1991 passim). These usually support an image of the horned god (variously interpreted as Baal-Hammon, Zeus-Hammon or a Cypriot deity using the iconography of these foreign deities (Sophocleous 1985,.58-69; Buchholz 1991; Counts 2008; Kleibel 2007). Bibliography: Buchholz H.-G. 1991, Der Gott Hammon und Zeus Hammon auf Zypern, AM 106, 85-108. Coenaerts J. and Samaes M. 2006, 'The ram throne: A true type of Cypriote furniture?', RDAC, 239-58. Counts D. 2008, 'From Siwa to Cyprus: The assimilation of Zeus Ammon in the Cypriote pantheon', in eds D. Michaelides et al, Egypt and Cyprus in Antiquity (Oxford and Oakville), 104-17. Kleibel K. 2007, 'The background of the Cypriot Ram God's iconography', in eds S. Christodoulou and A. Satraki, POCA 2007: Postgraduate Cypriot Archaeology Conference (Newcastle), 145-68. Sophocleous S. 1985, Atlas des représentations Cypro-Archaïques des divinités. SIMA Pocket-Book 33 (Göteborg).
Acquisition name: Donated by: Dr Herman Charles Hoskier
